Team \#538.Placement: Runner Up (Magna Cum Laude Team Prize)
Team \#538.Comments: This solution models Lake Powell's water volume, analyzes the impact on water supply and economy, and proposes water conservation strategies. It considers inflow, outflow, evaporation, and bank seepage. The solution also examines the effects on hydroelectric power generation and agricultural output. The response is well-organized and provides a clear methodology.

Q1.Definition: To model the changes in volume of water in Lake Powell over the next five years, while assuming that outflows of water remain at current levels.
Assumption: The output amount of water from Lake Powell will remain constant at 8.23 million acre-feet (MAF) per year.
The bank seepage rate will remain relatively constant at about 458 thousand acre-feet per year.
The amount of precipitation is assumed to be negligible.
The average annual water temperature of Lake Powell will remain relatively constant over the next five years, so this will not impact evaporation rates.
The amount and impact of snow is negligible; we assume that it is included in the inflow rate.
Q1.Model: dV/dt \= Inflow \+ Precip \- (Evap(V) \+ BankSeep \+ Outflow) \* t, where V(t) is the volume of water, Inflow is the inflow from the Colorado River, Precip is precipitation, Evap(V) is evaporation (a function of volume), BankSeep is bank seepage, and Outflow is the water released downstream. Evap(V) \= 0.00002531x \+ 48.33386921, where x is volume in acre-feet.  The model was then refined to account for minimum and maximum capacity constraints.
Results: Low inflow (39%): Lake would run dry.
Likely inflow (83%): Lake would gradually fill to 81.0% capacity.
High inflow (137%): Lake would reach 95% capacity and outflow would need to be increased.
Q1.Sensitivity Analysis: Tested the sensitivity of the model to small changes (1%) in inflow rates. Found that even small changes can have significant impacts on the total volume of the lake.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Considers multiple factors influencing water volume (inflow, outflow, evaporation, seepage).
Strength: Uses a differential equation to model the change in volume.
Weakness: Assumes constant outflow (initially), which is unrealistic.
Weakness: Relies on several simplifying assumptions (e.g., negligible precipitation, constant bank seepage).

Q2.Definition: Determine the impact of the projected lake outflows on the water supply and economy—including power generation—of the Lower Basin.
Assumption: Current water outflow is sufficient for the economy.
For the low estimate of water supply, outflow will equal inflow (minus water lost to bank seepage and evaporation) since maximum capacity has not yet been attained.
Water allocated to Native American tribes is not a significant amount of the total.
Model: Refined model with conditions to prevent the lake from running dry or overflowing:
If V(t) \> LP95: Outflow \= InflowNET \+ \[V(t) – LP95\]
If V(t) \< LP95 and (InflowNET \> OutflowNET): V(t) \= V(0) \+ InflowNET \* time – OutflowNET \* time
If V(t) \< LP95 and (InflowNET \< OutflowNET): Outflow \= InflowNET – \[Evap(V) \+ BankSeep\], V(t) \= V(0)
If V(t) \= LP95: Outflow \= InflowNET – \[Evap(V) \+ BankSeep\]
Hydroelectric power generation: Calculated based on the potential energy of water and dam efficiency.
Economic impact on agriculture: Estimated based on crop value per acre-foot of water.
Impact on municipal and industrial uses: Qualitative assessment, focusing on Las Vegas.
Impact on recreation: Qualitative assessment, considering Lake Mead and other recreational areas.
Results: Low inflow: Water supply to the Lower Basin would be significantly reduced.
Likely inflow: Lake would gradually fill, maintaining adequate water supply.
High inflow: Outflow would need to be increased to prevent overflow, increasing water supply to the Lower Basin.
Significant economic impacts on agriculture, municipal/industrial uses, and recreation are expected with reduced water availability.
Q2.Sensitivity Analysis: Not explicitly mentioned in this section.
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Refines the model to account for realistic constraints on lake volume.
Strength: Considers the impact on various economic sectors.
Weakness: Relies on several assumptions (e.g., constant dam efficiency, negligible water allocation to Native American tribes).
Weakness: Qualitative assessments for municipal/industrial and recreational impacts.

Q3.Definition: Recommend possible reductions to the amount of water removed from the Colorado River in an effort to maintain minimum capacity in Lake Powell.
Assumption: Crop production in the basin is evenly divided among crops that would pertain to the usage of drip irrigation (cotton, fruit, vegetables) and the usage of LEPA (wheat, alfalfa).
Economic costs of conservation are ignored.
85% of the water supplied is used in agriculture
Minimum capacity is equal to the current capacity of 13.1 MAF.
Results: Recommendations to reduce water consumption in agriculture (drip irrigation, LEPA).
Recommendations to reduce municipal and industrial water usage (more efficient appliances and fixtures).
Strength and Weakness: Strength: Provides specific recommendations for water conservation.
Weakness: Does not quantify the potential water savings from each recommendation.
Weakness: Does not consider the economic costs of implementing these recommendations.
